items.title: An experimental surgery is helping cancer survivors give birth
items.summary: This week I want to tell you about an experimental surgical procedure thatâ€™s helping people have babies. Specifically, itâ€™s helping people who have had treatment for bowel or rectal cancer. Radiation and chemo can have pretty damaging side effects that mess up the uterus and ovaries. Surgeons are pâ€¦
items.body: This week I want to tell you about an experimental surgical procedure thatâ€™s helping people have babies. Specifically, itâ€™s helping people who have had treatment for bowel or rectal cancer. Radiation and chemo can have pretty damaging side effects that mess up the uterus and ovaries. Surgeons are pioneering a potential solution: simply stitch those organs out of the way during cancer treatment. Once the treatment has finished, they can put the uterusâ€”along with the ovaries and fallopian tubesâ€”back into place. It seems to work!  Last week , a team in Switzerland shared news that a baby boy had been born after his mother had the procedure. Baby Lucien was the fifth baby to be born after the surgery and the first in Europe, says Daniela Huber, the gyno-oncologist who performed the operation. Since then, at least three others have been born, adds Reitan Ribeiro, the surgeon who pioneered the procedure. They told me the details. Huberâ€™s patient was 28 years old when a four-centimeter tumor was discovered in her rectum. Doctors at Sion Hospital in Switzerland, where Huber works, recommended a course of treatment that included multiple medications and radiotherapyâ€”the use of beams oâ€¦

items.title: Rees-Zammit and the question we're all asking

items.title: Consolidating systems for AI with iPaaS
items.summary: For decades, enterprises reacted to shifting business pressures with stopgap technology solutions. To rein in rising infrastructure costs, they adopted cloud services that could scale on demand. When customers shifted their lives onto smartphones, companies rolled out mobile apps to keep pace. And â€¦
items.body: For decades, enterprises reacted to shifting business pressures with stopgap technology solutions. To rein in rising infrastructure costs, they adopted cloud services that could scale on demand. When customers shifted their lives onto smartphones, companies rolled out mobile apps to keep pace. And when businesses began needing real-time visibility into factories and stockrooms, they layered on IoT systems to supply those insights. Each new plug-in or platform promised better, more efficient operations. And individually, many delivered. But as more and more solutions stacked up, IT teams had to string together a tangled web to connect themâ€”less an IT ecosystem and more of a make-do collection of ad-hoc workarounds. DOWNLOAD THE REPORT That reality has led to bottlenecks and maintenance burdens, and the impact is showing up in performance. Today, fewer than half of CIOs (48%) say their current digital initiatives are meeting or exceeding business outcome targets. Another 2025 survey found that operations leaders point to integration complexity and data quality issues as top culprits for why investments havenâ€™t delivered as expected. Achim Kraiss, chief product officer of SAP Integraâ€¦

items.body: This is today’s edition of The Download , our weekday newsletter that provides a daily dose of what’s going on in the world of technology. This is the most misunderstood graph in AI Every time OpenAI, Google, or Anthropic drops a new frontier large language model, the AI community holds its breath. It doesnâ€™t exhale until METR, an AI research nonprofit whose name stands for â€œModel Evaluation & Threat Research,â€ updates a now-iconic graph that has played a major role in the AI discourse since it was first released in March of last year.  The graph suggests that certain AI capabilities are developing at an exponential rate, and more recent model releases have outperformed that already impressive trend. That was certainly the case for Claude Opus 4.5, the latest version of Anthropicâ€™s most powerful model, which was released in late November. In December, METR announced that Opus 4.5 appeared to be capable of independently completing a task that would have taken a human about five hoursâ€”a vast improvement over what even the exponential trend would have predicted. But the truth is more complicated than those dramatic responses would suggest. Read the full story . â€”â€¦

items.title: Three questions about next-generation nuclear power, answered
items.summary: Nuclear power continues to be one of the hottest topics in energy today, and in our recent online Roundtables discussion about next-generation nuclear power, hyperscale AI data centers, and the grid, we got dozens of great audience questions. These ran the gamut, and while we answered quite a few (â€¦
items.body: Nuclear power continues to be one of the hottest topics in energy today, and in our recent online Roundtables discussion about next-generation nuclear power , hyperscale AI data centers , and the grid, we got dozens of great audience questions. These ran the gamut, and while we answered quite a few (and Iâ€™m keeping some in mind for future reporting), there were a bunch we couldnâ€™t get to, at least not in the depth I would have liked. So letâ€™s answer a few of your questions about advanced nuclear power. Iâ€™ve combined similar ones and edited them for clarity. How are the fuel needs for next-generation nuclear reactors different, and how are companies addressing the supply chain? Many next-generation reactors donâ€™t use the low-enriched uranium used in conventional reactors. Itâ€™s worth looking at high-assay low-enriched uranium, or HALEU, specifically. This fuel is enriched to higher concentrations of fissile uranium than conventional nuclear fuel, with a proportion of the isotope U-235 that falls between 5% and 20%. (In conventional fuel, itâ€™s below 5%.) HALEU can be produced with the same technology as low-enriched uranium, but the geopolitics are complicated. Today, Russia basicallâ€¦

items.title: This is the most misunderstood graph in AI
items.summary: MIT Technology Review Explains: Let our writers untangle the complex, messy world of technology to help you understand whatâ€™s coming next. You can read more from the series here. Every time OpenAI, Google, or Anthropic drops a new frontier large language model, the AI community holds its breath. Itâ€¦
items.body: MIT Technology Review Explains: Let our writers untangle the complex, messy world of technology to help you understand whatâ€™s coming next. You can read more from the series here . Every time OpenAI, Google, or Anthropic drops a new frontier large language model, the AI community holds its breath. It doesnâ€™t exhale until METR, an AI research nonprofit whose name stands for â€œModel Evaluation & Threat Research,â€ updates a now-iconic graph that has played a major role in the AI discourse since it was first released in March of last year. The graph suggests that certain AI capabilities are developing at an exponential rate, and more recent model releases have outperformed that already impressive trend. That was certainly the case for Claude Opus 4.5, the latest version of Anthropicâ€™s most powerful model, which was released in late November. In December, METR announced that Opus 4.5 appeared to be capable of independently completing a task that would have taken a human about five hoursâ€”a vast improvement over what even the exponential trend would have predicted. One Anthropic safety researcher tweeted that he would change the direction of his research in light of those results; anotâ€¦

items.title: The Download: the future of nuclear power plants, and social media-fueled AI hype
items.summary: This is todayâ€™s edition of The Download, our weekday newsletter that provides a daily dose of whatâ€™s going on in the world of technology. Why AI companies are betting on next-gen nuclear AI is driving unprecedented investment for massive data centers and an energy supply that can support its huge câ€¦
items.body: This is today’s edition of The Download , our weekday newsletter that provides a daily dose of what’s going on in the world of technology. Why AI companies are betting on next-gen nuclear AI is driving unprecedented investment for massive data centers and an energy supply that can support its huge computational appetite. One potential source of electricity for these facilities is next-generation nuclear power plants , which could be cheaper to construct and safer to operate than their predecessors. We recently held a subscriber-exclusive Roundtables discussion on hyperscale AI data centers and next-gen nuclear â€”two featured technologies on the MIT Technology Review 10 Breakthrough Technologies of 2026 list . You can watch the conversation back here , and donâ€™t forget to subscribe to make sure you catch future discussions as they happen. How social media encourages the worst of AI boosterism Demis Hassabis, CEO of Google DeepMind, summed it up in three words: â€œThis is embarrassing.â€ Hassabis was replying on X to an overexcited post by SÃ©bastien Bubeck, a research scientist at the rival firm OpenAI, announcing that two mathematicians had used OpenAIâ€™s latest large languaâ€¦

items.body: This is today’s edition of The Download , our weekday newsletter that provides a daily dose of what’s going on in the world of technology. Microbes could extract the metal needed for cleantech In a pine forest on Michiganâ€™s Upper Peninsula, the only active nickel mine in the US is nearing the end of its life. At a time when carmakers want the metal for electric-vehicle batteries, nickel concentration at Eagle Mine is falling and could soon drop too low to warrant digging. Demand for nickel, copper, and rare earth elements is rapidly increasing amid the explosive growth of metal-intensive data centers, electric cars, and renewable energy projects. But producing these metals is becoming harder and more expensive because miners have already exploited the best resources. Hereâ€™s how biotechnology could help . â€”Matt Blois What weâ€™ve been getting wrong about AIâ€™s truth crisis â€”James O’Donnell What would it take to convince you that the era of truth decay we were long warned aboutâ€”where AI content dupes us, shapes our beliefs even when we catch the lie, and erodes societal trust in the processâ€”is now here? A story I published last week pushed me over the edge. And it alsâ€¦

items.title: Microbes could extract the metal needed for cleantech
items.summary: In a pine forest on Michiganâ€™s Upper Peninsula, the only active nickel mine in the US is nearing the end of its life. At a time when carmakers want the metal for electric-vehicle batteries, nickel concentration at Eagle Mine is falling and could soon drop too low to warrant digging. But earlier thiâ€¦
items.body: In a pine forest on Michiganâ€™s Upper Peninsula, the only active nickel mine in the US is nearing the end of its life. At a time when carmakers want the metal for electric-vehicle batteries, nickel concentration at Eagle Mine is falling and could soon drop too low to warrant digging. But earlier this year, the mineâ€™s owner started testing a new process that could eke out a bit more nickel. In a pair of shipping containers recently installed at the mineâ€™s mill, a fermentation-derived broth developed by the startup Allonnia is mixed with concentrated ore to capture and remove impurities. The process allows nickel production from lower-quality ore.  Kent Sorenson, Allonniaâ€™s chief technology officer, says this approach could help companies continue operating sites that, like Eagle Mine, have burned through their best ore. â€œThe low-hanging fruit is to keep mining the mines that we have,â€ he says.  Demand for nickel, copper, and rare earth elements is rapidly increasing amid the explosive growth of metal-intensive data centers, electric cars, and renewable energy projects. But producing these metals is becoming harder and more expensive because miners have already exploited thâ€¦

items.title: What weâ€™ve been getting wrong about AIâ€™s truth crisis
items.summary: This story originally appeared in The Algorithm, our weekly newsletter on AI. To get stories like this in your inbox first, sign up here. What would it take to convince you that the era of truth decay we were long warned aboutâ€”where AI content dupes us, shapes our beliefs even when we catch the lieâ€¦
items.body: This story originally appeared in The Algorithm, our weekly newsletter on AI. To get stories like this in your inbox first,  sign up here . What would it take to convince you that the era of truth decay we were long warned aboutâ€”where AI content dupes us, shapes our beliefs even when we catch the lie, and erodes societal trust in the processâ€”is now here? A story I published last week pushed me over the edge. It also made me realize that the tools we were sold as a cure for this crisis are failing miserably.  On Thursday, I reported the first confirmation that the US Department of Homeland Security, which houses immigration agencies, is using AI video generators from Google and Adobe to make content that it shares with the public. The news comes as immigration agencies have flooded social media with content to support President Trump’s mass deportation agendaâ€”some of which appears to be made with AI (like a video about â€œChristmas after mass deportationsâ€). But I received two types of reactions from readers that may explain just as much about the epistemic crisis weâ€™re in.  One was from people who werenâ€™t surprised, because on January 22 the White House had postâ€¦

items.title: Tactics, transfers and turmoil - inside the fall of Amorim
items.summary: After 14 months, Ruben Amorim has been sacked by Manchester United - but where did it all go wrong?

items.title: Booze, beach, beaten - how England lost the Ashes
items.summary: BBC Sport chief cricket reporter Stephan Shemilt reveals the inside story of England's Ashes defeat in Australia on and off the pitch.

items.title: I've realised I can make a difference - Hoy
items.summary: In a new BBC documentary, Sir Chris Hoy shows how he is using his Olympic mindset to reframe his purpose following a terminal cancer diagnosis.

items.title: Inside McLaren's season - the rules, values, incidents & relationships
items.summary: Intra-team title battles turn toxic far more often than not. Andrew Benson analyses how McLaren have maintained relative harmony between Lando Norris and Oscar Piastri.
